Award.AwardTitle: Workshop Proposal: The Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves and Special Values of L-Functions, May 2-4, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop "Arithmetic of elliptic curves and special values of L-functions" will take place May 2-4, 2014 at the University of Illinois at Chicago. This is part of the annual Oliver Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop at UIC. The website of the workshop is http://www.math.uic.edu/~rtakloo/atkin2014.html. The theme of the workshop is the recent progress regarding special values of L-functions and its applications to the arithmetic of elliptic curves. Of particular interest will be the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture, Gross-Zagier-Zhang formulae, Main Conjecture of Iwasawa Theory, etc. The workshop will bring together experts working in the area and will create an environment in which participants may exchange ideas and start new projects.

Funding from the National Science Foundation makes it possible for junior researchers, graduate students, and other mathematicians without travel funds to attend this exciting workshop. This is an excellent opportunity for them to interact with experts in the field and to be inspired for further work. The lectures by invited speakers will take place on May 3 and 4, and time is also reserved for talks by participating recent Ph.D. recipients and graduate students. Select lectures will be videotaped and made available to the mathematical community on a website. The slides of talks will be made available on the same website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop with the title of “Expansion in Linear Groups” was organized. The organizers were Ramin Takloo-Bighash (UIC) and Alireza Salehi-Golsefidy (UC San Diego). This workshop was part of the annual Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop held at UIC in the memory of the UIC’s professor emeritus Oliver Atkin. The 2014 Atkin Lecture and Workshop was funded by NSF workshop grant DMS- 1519561. Additional funds were acquired from Frank Calegari’s CAREER grant and UIC’s visitor funds. For this reason there was some leftover funds from the grant, and these funds, with approval from the grant officer, were used to funds the participants of a later workshop “Midwest Number Theory Conference for Graduate Students and Recent PhD’s” at UIC, Oct 16-18, 2015.

Salehi-Golsefidy delivered the Atkin lecture on Friday, May 1, 2015 at 3 PM. The lecture was attended by approximately 120 people. The workshop on Saturday and Sunday was attended by about 50 people the majority of whom were funded by a combination of funds from the grant, Frank Calegari’s CAREER grant, and UIC. The list of the participants funded by the grant is attached. Attached you will also find the list of the people funded to attend the Midwest Number Theory Conference.

There were eleven lectures in the Atkin workshop. The speakers were: Remi Boutonnet (UCSD), Elena Fuchs (UIUC), Alex Furman (UIC), Alex Gamburd (CUNY), Harald Helfgott (CNRS Paris VI/VII), Alex Kontorovich (Rutgers), Igor Rivin (Temple), Alireza Salehi-Golsefidi (UCSD) Nicolas de Saxce (Hebrew University of Jerusalem). The principal speakers of the Midwest Number Theory Conference were: Mirela Ciperiani (UT-Austin), Matthew Emerton (University of Chicago), Brooke Feigon (CUNY), Nathan Jones (UIC), and Kartik Prasanna (University of Michigan). There were also numerous lectures by the junior participants.

The annual Atkin Memorial Lecture is aimed at remembering Oliver Atkin's lasting contributions to mathematics and the University of Illinois. The previous speakers are Ken Ono (2009), Steve Kudla (2010), Winnie Li (2011), William Stein (2012), Akshay Venkatesh (2013), and Shou-wu Zhang (2014).

Additional information about the Atkin Workshop can be found at: https://sites.google.com/site/rtakloo/atkin-lecture-and-workshop

Additional information about the Midwest Number Theory conference can be found here: https://sites.google.com/a/uic.edu/2015mwntc/

Intellectual Merits: 

The workshop concentrated on recent progress on the connections between the arithmetic of linear algebraic groups, random walks, and dynamical systems. 

Broader Impact: 

Most of the speakers and participants of the workshop were mathematicians in the early stages of their career. The workshop provided these mathematicians with a wonderful opportunity to interact with established experts and learn about the recent progress in the subject.
